text: Also interested to see the answers. :raised_hands:

elements.text: Also interested to see the answers.

text: Hey folks, quick question. While designing an editorial strategy, what are some of the key business goals that we should keep in mind? Brand awareness for one, credibility, boosting customer loyalty are a few I can think off. Any suggestions would be welcome. TIA

elements.text: Hey folks, quick question. While designing an editorial strategy, what are some of the key business goals that we should keep in mind? Brand awareness for one, credibility, boosting customer loyalty are a few I can think off. Any suggestions would be welcome. TIA

text: Conversion. And then micro-conversions like email capture, organic traffic increase etc. come above Brand Awareness imo (and are easier to measure).

elements.text: Conversion. And then micro-conversions like email capture, organic traffic increase etc. come above Brand Awareness imo (and are easier to measure).

text: Audience size/growth - e.g. increase in blog subscribers, social media followers, etc.

elements.text: Audience size/growth - e.g. increase in blog subscribers, social media followers, etc.

text:
Per _Good Strategy/Bad Strategy_ by Richard P. Rumelt (highly recommend BTW) a good strategy consists of:
• a diagnosis
• a guiding policy
• a coherent action plan to carry out the guiding policy
Given the above, focusing up front on goals like awareness, credibility, etc. would be counter productive.

Most often editorial strategy revolves around conversions, as Jane mentioned, but what those are and how you want to incentivise them depends heavily on your unique circumstances.

text: Ronia, you might want to take a look at this thread by <@U019SM5LH6D> → <https://content-career-growth.slack.com/archives/CUYDAGXKR/p1646408297939349> :slightly_smiling_face:

elements.text: Hi all! Long post to follow about measuring the
business impact

of content. Would love to hear how you all address this in your orgs.

My team is talking content reporting/metrics and I'd love to get some input -- measurement and reporting are definitely not my strong suit. As far as I can tell, measurements fall into two different buckets:
How "hook-y" is the content?
- Is it bringing in new leads/bringing new people to our website?
Is the content high-quality?

- Is it of interest to our audience, and is it helping move them down the sales funnel?

The first lends itself to more classic content metrics (downloads, MoM organic blog traffic growth, etc), but the second is trickier. We can measure things like webinar audience attendance rate to see if people are engaging with the content, but that doesn't help make the leap to whether we're engaging with our target audience. I'm thinking we need to be measuring something like Pipeline Influenced or Opportunities Influenced, but the feedback is that those metrics belong to other depts. (Opportunities Influenced, for example, would be owned by Sales Enablement, which coaches the sales team on how to use the content created by my team.)

We're currently kicking around
Inquiry -> AQL conversion rate

(which theoretically is measuring the success of our lead warming email campaigns, which use content to increase people's lead score to the point we believe they're ready to be contacted by sales). I don't think this fully captures the impact of our content.

Any thoughts on the best way to measure the
business impact
of content? I realize this is a perennial struggle for content marketers, so I'd also love to have a conversation with anyone who has strong opinions on this!

Hi all! Long post to follow about measuring the *business impact* of content. Would love to hear how you all address this in your orgs.

My team is talking content reporting/metrics and I'd love to get some input -- measurement and reporting are definitely not my strong suit. As far as I can tell, measurements fall into two different buckets:
1. *How "hook-y" is the content?* - Is it bringing in new leads/bringing new people to our website?
2. *Is the content high-quality?* - Is it of interest to our audience, and is it helping move them down the sales funnel?

The first lends itself to more classic content metrics (downloads, MoM organic blog traffic growth, etc), but the second is trickier. We can measure things like webinar audience attendance rate to see if people are engaging with the content, but that doesn't help make the leap to whether we're engaging with our target audience. I'm thinking we need to be measuring something like Pipeline Influenced or Opportunities Influenced, but the feedback is that those metrics belong to other depts. (Opportunities Influenced, for example, would be owned by Sales Enablement, which coaches the sales team on how to use the content created by my team.)

We're currently kicking around *Inquiry -> AQL conversion rate* (which theoretically is measuring the success of our lead warming email campaigns, which use content to increase people's lead score to the point we believe they're ready to be contacted by sales). I don't think this fully captures the impact of our content.

Any thoughts on the best way to measure the *business impact* of content? I realize this is a perennial struggle for content marketers, so I'd also love to have a conversation with anyone who has strong opinions on this!

text: Do you pre-write meta descriptions as part of your content briefs? Or wait until the article’s written to write it?

elements.text: Do you pre-write meta descriptions as part of your content briefs? Or wait until the article’s written to write it?

text: I write them once the article’s done, just in case there’s a nicer way to wing it in the meta (and make it less dull)

elements.text: I write them once the article’s done, just in case there’s a nicer way to wing it in the meta (and make it less dull)

text: Yeah, writing it at the end seems to be the better way. I get some clients asking for meta descriptions at the brief phase, but I’m considering enforcing a hard “no” until we get the draft.

elements.text: Yeah, writing it at the end seems to be the better way. I get some clients asking for meta descriptions at the brief phase, but I’m considering enforcing a hard “no” until we get the draft.

text:
<@U011QQDDSJV> Writing it at the end would be better. There are multiple reasons to this.

1. You can get an overall idea about how to prepare your meta on the basis of the content  that's ready.
2. It's always good to analyse SERP and before preparing your meta. And since SERP results keep changing, doing the analysis before going live would make more sense.
3. Like <@U030VMS2T4M>, there will always be nicer to way to wing in the meta after your content is ready. It can be a CTA, or some additional attributes you would have covered in your content or some other X factor that can make you stand out in SERP.

It's always good to analyse SERP and before preparing your meta. And since SERP results keep changing, doing the analysis before going live would make more sense.
